channel.title: Playing a private server on Linux
channel.description:
So I have absolutely no idea how to do it can someone help? I will use teamview if nesacary.
P,s, I'm a total noob at linux and have absolutely no idea how to use it so in as simple terms as possible >.>

Did you try downloading moparscape and running it?

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @cyco cyco
item.description:
@cyco wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:21, topic:292503”][quote author=cyco link=topic=386442.msg2899441#msg2899441 date=1249424373]

First of all, you can download moparscape and that will run on linux without a hitch. Secondly, you can go to http://www.moparisthebest.com and play the webclient there, all you have to do is install sun-java6-plugin with your package manager (or ‘sudo apt-get install sun-java6-plugin’ on the command line)

I did this and and every time I try to run moparscape it just shuts down my firefox

[/quote]

That’s happened to me once before, but only once.[/quote]
It happens to me every time =\

Read full topic

Secondly, you can go to http://www.moparisthebest.com and play the webclient there, all you have to do is install sun-java6-plugin with your package manager (or ‘sudo apt-get install sun-java6-plugin’ on the command line)

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

yes, iirc it saves it to a directory in your home directory

It should, but for some reason it always downloads to /tmp

I have fixed this in the forthcoming version of moparscape however, so coupled with the update server (so you only download what you need when you need it) everything is much faster and you only have to download things once.

Read full topic
item.source: Playing a private server on Linux

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

eczema3:

That’s where RuneScape fails, if you want to play RS on linux you have to redownload the cache everytime the client is loaded. Which sux

wat


	public static String findcachedir() {
		String startPaths[] = { "c:/windows/", "c:/winnt/", "d:/windows/", "d:/winnt/",
				"e:/windows/", "e:/winnt/", "f:/windows/", "f:/winnt/", "c:/",
				"~/", "/tmp/", "", "c:/rscache", "/rscache" };

                if (storeid < 32 || storeid > 34)
			storeid = 32;

		String cacheFolder = ".file_store_" + storeid;
		for (int i = 0; i < startPaths.length; i++)
			try {
				String currentStartPath = startPaths[i];
				if (currentStartPath.length() > 0) {
					java.io.File file = new java.io.File(currentStartPath);
					if (!file.exists())
						continue;
				}
				java.io.File fullCachePath = new java.io.File(currentStartPath + cacheFolder);
				if (fullCachePath.exists() || fullCachePath.mkdir())
					return currentStartPath + cacheFolder + "/";
			} catch (Exception _ex) {
			}

		return null;
	}

It can save to home or tmp depending on if home is writable or not (which it should be).

Read full topic

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @Tulitikku Tulitikku
item.description:
@Tulitikku wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:5, topic:292503”][quote author=Tulitikku link=topic=386442.msg2896389#msg2896389 date=1249244745]
Playing on a client usually makes the icons overlap, making PKing pretty much impossible. What I did was I installed Java 6u7 (Other ones wouldn’t install) on Wine.
Then to run it, simply do this:

wine java -Xmx512m Gui

Anybody with a better solution, please tell it…
[/quote]
You’re a fool.

cyco, open up a terminal window and type; sudo apt-get install sun-java6-jdk sun-java6-fonts sun-java6-bin
That will install about 60 - 70mb of files and will allow you to do anything with an rsps you need to, it will also allow you to play on 508 clients and play runescape too. Although a known bug when playing runescape is once runescape starts, it ‘eats’ Alsa(Sound driver) so you cant play any more sounds while runescape is open, but close it and all is well.[/quote]Well, I asked some Indian guy that has been using Linux for 2 years, and that was his answer. Talking about 317’s then, never played a 508 on Linux, so dunno about them.
@T4, I know, it sounds quite horrid, but I seriously haven’t thought of any better option for fixing overlapping icons.

Read full topic
item.source: Playing a private server on Linux

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Tulitikku, post:4, topic:292503”]Playing on a client usually makes the icons overlap, making PKing pretty much impossible. What I did was I installed Java 6u7 (Other ones wouldn’t install) on Wine.
Then to run it, simply do this:

wine java -Xmx512m Gui

Anybody with a better solution, please tell it…[/quote]
Using native methods to load images and using a ported software library to run multi-platform software… You sir are beyond retarded.

Read full topic
item.source: Playing a private server on Linux

item.title: Playing a private server on Linux
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Tulitikku, post:4, topic:292503”]Playing on a client usually makes the icons overlap, making PKing pretty much impossible. What I did was I installed Java 6u7 (Other ones wouldn’t install) on Wine.
Then to run it, simply do this:

wine java -Xmx512m Gui

Anybody with a better solution, please tell it…[/quote]
You’re a fool.

cyco, open up a terminal window and type; sudo apt-get install sun-java6-jdk sun-java6-fonts sun-java6-bin
That will install about 60 - 70mb of files and will allow you to do anything with an rsps you need to, it will also allow you to play on 508 clients and play runescape too. Although a known bug when playing runescape is once runescape starts, it ‘eats’ Alsa(Sound driver) so you cant play any more sounds while runescape is open, but close it and all is well.

Read full topic
